sen.j: 半幅帯（はんはばおび）は、日本で使用される女帯の一種。
sen.e: Hanhaba-obi is a kind onna-obi (a broad sash for a female) that is used in Japan.
The hanhaba obi is a kind women's obi sash used in Japan.

Its another names are hoso-obi and yonsun-obi.

sen.j: 並幅（約36センチ）を半分に折って（鯨尺で4寸）仕立てることからいう。
sen.e: This name derived from the fact that it is made after folding a textile of standard width (about 36 cm) in half (yonsun (12.12 cm) measured by kujirajaku (a measuring stick used in kimono-makingsun)).

sen.e: It is an informal obi that is not used in public places in principle, except for the cases where it is used invisibly, such as under haori (a Japanese half-coat) or uchikake (long outer robe).

sen.e: Hanhaba-obi made of nishiki (brocade) is often used for decorated yukata of folk dancing with the aim of creating glamorous air.

sen.e: This is because folk dancing, which originated from people's folkways and has become theatrical art, needs glamorous air as theatrical art while maintaining traditional appearance such as costume etc.
